member.name: T:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialStopBits
member.summary: Number of stop bits appended to a serial character
member.remarks: This enumeration specifies the number of stop bits to use. Stop bits separate each unit of data on an asynchronous serial connection. The None option is not supported. Setting the StopBits property to None raises an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialParity.Even
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an even number.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialParity.Mark
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 1.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialParity.None
member.summary: No parity check occurs.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialParity.Odd
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an odd number.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialParity.Space
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 0.

member.name: T:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialParity
member.summary: The type of parity used on the serial port
member.remarks: Parity is an error-checking procedure in which the number of 1s must always be the same — either even or odd — for each group of bits that is transmitted without error. Parity is one of the parameters that must be agreed upon by both sending and receiving parties before transmission can take place.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialHandshake.None
member.summary: No control is used for the handshake.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialHandshake.RequestToSend
member.summary: Request-to-Send (RTS) hardware flow control is used. RTS signals that data is available for transmission. If the input buffer becomes full, the RTS line will be set to false. The RTS line will be set to true when more room becomes available in the input buffer.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialHandshake.RequestToSendXonXoff
member.summary: Both the Request-to-Send (RTS) hardware control and the XON/XOFF software controls are used.

member.name: F:ASCOM.Utilities.SerialHandshake.XonXoff
member.summary: The XON/XOFF software control protocol is used. The XOFF control is sent to stop the transmission of data. The XON control is sent to resume the transmission. These software controls are used instead of Request to Send (RTS) and Clear to Send (CTS) hardware controls.

member.name: T:ASCOM.Utilities.Serial
member.summary: Creates a .NET serial port and provides a simple set of commands to use it.
member.remarks: This object provides an easy to use interface to a serial (COM) port. It provides ASCII and binary I/O with controllable timeout. It is limited to 8 bit, no parity, one stop-bit modes. The interface is callable from any .NET client.
member.example: Example of how to create and use an ASCOM serial port.

member.name: T:ASCOM.Utilities.Exceptions.SerialPortInUseException
member.summary: Exception thrown when a serial port method is already in progress and a second attempt is made to use the serial port.
member.remarks: This exception is only thrown after 5 attempts, each with a 1 second timeout, have been made to acquire the serial port. It may indicate that you have more than one thread attempting to access the serial port and that you have not synchronised these within your application. The serial port can only handle one transaction at a time e.g. Serial.Receive or Serial.Transmit etc.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.LogMessage(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Logs a complete message in one call
member.param: Identifies the meaning of the the message e.g. name of modeule or method logging the message.
Message to log

remarks.para: Use this for straightforward logging requrements. Writes all information in one command.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line started by LogStart has been closed with LogFinish. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.
This overload is not available through COM, please use "LogMessage(ByVal Identifier As String, ByVal Message As String, ByVal HexDump As Boolean)" with HexDump set False to achieve this effect.

member.param: Identifies the meaning of the the message e.g. name of modeule or method logging the message.
Message to log
True to append a hex translation of the message at the end of the message

remarks.para: Use this for straightforward logging requrements. Writes all information in one command.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line started by LogStart has been closed with LogFinish. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.LogStart(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes the time and identifier to the log, leaving the line ready for further content through LogContinue and LogFinish
member.param: Identifies the meaning of the the message e.g. name of modeule or method logging the message.
Message to log

remarks.para: Use this to start a log line where you want to write further information on the line at a later time.

E.g. You might want to use this to record that an action has started and then append the word OK if all went well. You would then end up with just one line to record the whole transaction even though you didn't know that it would be successful when you started. If you just used LogMsg you would have ended up with two log lines, one showing the start of the transaction and the next the outcome.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line started by LogStart has been closed with LogFinish. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.LogContinue(System.String)
member.summary: Appends further message to a line started by LogStart, does not terminate the line.
member.param: The additional message to appear in the line

remarks.para: This can be called multiple times to build up a complex log line if required.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line has been started with LogStart. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.
This overload is not available through COM, please use "LogContinue(ByVal Message As String, ByVal HexDump As Boolean)" with HexDump set False to achieve this effect.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.LogContinue(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Appends further message to a line started by LogStart, appends a hex translation of the message to the line, does not terminate the line.
member.param: The additional message to appear in the line
True to append a hex translation of the message at the end of the message

remarks.para: This can be called multiple times to build up a complex log line if required.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line has been started with LogStart. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.LogFinish(System.String)
member.summary: Closes a line started by LogStart with the supplied message
member.param: The final message to terminate the line

remarks.para: Can only be called once for each line started by LogStart.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line has been started with LogStart. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.
This overload is not available through COM, please use "LogFinish(ByVal Message As String, ByVal HexDump As Boolean)" with HexDump set False to achieve this effect.

member.name: P:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.Enabled
member.summary: Enables or disables logging to the file.
member.value: True to enable logging
member.returns: Boolean, current logging status (enabled/disabled).
member.remarks: If this property is false then calls to LogMsg, LogStart, LogContinue and LogFinish do nothing. If True, supplied messages are written to the log file.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger.SetLogFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the log filename and type if the constructor is called without parameters
member.param: Fully qualified trace file name or null string to use automatic file naming (recommended)
String identifying the type of log e,g, Focuser, LX200, GEMINI, MoonLite, G11
member.remarks:
The LogFileType is used in the file name to allow you to quickly identify which of several logs contains the information of interest.
Note This command is only required if the tracelogger constructor is called with no parameters. It is provided for use in COM clients that can not call constructors with parameters. If you are writing a COM client then create the trace logger as:
TL = New TraceLogger() TL.SetLogFile("","TraceName")
If you are writing a .NET client then you can achieve the same end in one call:
TL = New TraceLogger("",TraceName")

member.name: T:ASCOM.Utilities.TraceLogger
member.summary: Creates a log file for a driver or application. Uses a similar file name and internal format to the serial logger. Multiple logs can be created simultaneously if needed.

remarks.para: In automatic mode the file will be stored in an ASCOM folder within XP's My Documents folder or equivalent places in other operating systems. Within the ASCOM folder will be a folder named Logs yyyy-mm-dd where yyyy, mm and dd are today's year, month and day numbers. The trace file will appear within the day folder with the name ASCOM.Identifier.hhmm.ssffff where hh, mm, ss and ffff are the current hour, minute, second and fraction of second numbers at the time of file creation.

Within the file the format of each line is hh:mm:ss.fff Identifier Message where hh, mm, ss and fff are the hour, minute, second and fractional second at the time that the message was logged, Identifier is the supplied identifier (usually the subroutine, function, property or method from which the message is sent) and Message is the message to be logged.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.ITraceLogger.LogStart(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes the time and identifier to the log, leaving the line ready for further content through LogContinue and LogFinish
member.param: Identifies the meaning of the the message e.g. name of modeule or method logging the message.
Message to log

remarks.para: Use this to start a log line where you want to write further information on the line at a later time.

E.g. You might want to use this to record that an action has started and then append the word OK if all went well. You would then end up with just one line to record the whole transaction even though you didn't know that it would be successful when you started. If you just used LogMsg you would have ended up with two log lines, one showing the start of the transaction and the next the outcome.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line started by LogStart has been closed with LogFinish. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.ITraceLogger.LogContinue(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Appends further message to a line started by LogStart, appends a hex translation of the message to the line, does not terminate the line.
member.param: The additional message to appear in the line
True to append a hex translation of the message at the end of the message

remarks.para: This can be called multiple times to build up a complex log line if required.

Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line has been started with LogStart. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.

member.summary: Closes a line started by LogStart with option to append a translation of the supplied message into HEX
member.param: The final message to appear in the line
True to append a hex translation of the message at the end of the message

remarks.para: Will create a LOGISSUE message in the log if called before a line has been started with LogStart. Posible reasons for this are exceptions causing the normal flow of code to be bypassed or logic errors.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.ITraceLogger.SetLogFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the log filename and type if the constructor is called without parameters
member.param: Fully qualified trace file name or null string to use automatic file naming (recommended)
String identifying the type of log e,g, Focuser, LX200, GEMINI, MoonLite, G11
member.remarks:
The LogFileType is used in the file name to allow you to quickly identify which of several logs contains the information of interest.
Note This command is only required if the tracelogger constructor is called with no parameters. It is provided for use in COM clients that can not call constructors with parameters. If you are writing a COM client then create the trace logger as:
TL = New TraceLogger() TL.SetLogFile("","TraceName")
If you are writing a .NET client then you can achieve the same end in one call:
TL = New TraceLogger("",TraceName")

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IUtil.WaitForMilliseconds(System.Int32)
member.summary: Pauses for a given interval in milliseconds.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait
member.remarks: Repeatedly puts the calling Win32 process to sleep, totally freezing it, for 10 milliseconds, then pumps events so the script or program calling it will receive its normal flow of events, until the pause interval elapses. If the pause interval is 20 milliseconds or less, the sleep interval is reduced to 0, causing the calling Win32 process to give up control to the kernel scheduler and then immediately become eligible for scheduling.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IUtil.DMSToDegrees(System.String)
member.summary: Convert sexagesimal degrees to binary double-precision degrees
member.param: The sexagesimal input string (degrees)
member.returns: The double-precision binary value (degrees) represented by the sexagesimal input

remarks.para: The sexagesimal to real conversion methods such as this one are flexible enough to convert just about anything that resembles sexagesimal. Thee way they operate is to first separate the input string into numeric "tokens", strings consisting only of the numerals 0-9, plus and minus, and period. All other characters are considered delimiters. Once the input string is parsed into tokens they are converted to numerics.

If there are more than three numeric tokens, only the first three are considered, the remainder are ignored. Left to right positionally, the tokens are assumed to represent units (degrees or hours), minutes, and seconds. If only two tokens are present, they are assumed to be units and minutes, and if only one token is present, it is assumed to be units. Any token can have a fractionsl part. Of course it would not be normal (for example) for both the minutes and seconds parts to have fractional parts, but it would be legal. So 00:30.5:30 would convert to 1.0 unit.
Note that plain units, for example 23.128734523 are acceptable to the method.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IUtil.HMSToHours(System.String)
member.summary: Convert sexagesimal hours to binary double-precision hours
member.param: The sexagesimal input string (hours)
member.returns: The double-precision binary value (hours) represented by the sexagesimal input

All other characters are considered delimiters. Once the input string is parsed into tokens they are converted to numerics.

Descriptive name of the device

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.Unregister(System.String)
member.summary: Remove all data for the given DriverID from the registry.
member.param: ProgID of the device to unregister

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.GetValue(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Retrieve a string value from the profile using the supplied subkey for the given Driver ID and variable name.
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Name of the variable whose value is retrieved
Subkey from the profile root from which to read the value
member.returns: Retrieved variable value

remarks.para: Name may be an empty string for the unnamed value. The unnamed value is also known as the "default" value for a registry key.
Does not provide access to other registry data types such as binary and doubleword.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.WriteValue(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes a string value to the profile using the supplied subkey for the given Driver ID and variable name.
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Name of the variable whose value is retrieved
The string value to be written
Subkey from the profile root in which to write the value

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.Values(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Return a list of the (unnamed and named variables) under the given DriverID. (for COM clients)
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Subkey from the profile root in which to write the value
member.returns: An ArrayList of KeyValuePair objects.
member.remarks:
The returned object contains entries for each value. For each entry, the Key property is the value's name, and the Value property is the string value itself. Note that the unnamed (default) value will be included if it has a value, even if the value is a blank string. The unnamed value will have its entry's Key property set to an empty string.
The KeyValuePair objects are instances of the KeyValuePair class

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.DeleteValue(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Delete the value from the registry. Name may be an empty string for the unnamed value. Value will be deleted from the subkey supplied.
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Name of the variable whose value is retrieved
Subkey from the profile root in which to write the value
member.remarks: Specify "" to delete the unnamed value which is also known as the "default" value for a registry key.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.CreateSubKey(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Create a registry key for the given DriverID.
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Subkey from the profile root in which to write the value
member.remarks: If the SubKey argument contains a \ separated path, the intermediate keys will be created if needed.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.SubKeys(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Return a list of the sub-keys under the given DriverID (for COM clients)
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Subkey from the profile root in which to search for subkeys
member.returns: An ArrayList of key-value pairs
member.remarks:
The returned object (scripting.dictionary) contains entries for each sub-key. For each KeyValuePair in the list, the Key property is the sub-key name, and the Value property is the value. The unnamed ("default") value for that key is also returned.
The KeyValuePair objects are instances of the KeyValuePair class

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.IProfile.DeleteSubKey(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Delete a registry key for the given DriverID. SubKey may contain \ separated path to key to be deleted.
member.param: ProgID of the device to read from
Subkey from the profile root in which to write the value
member.remarks: The sub-key and all data and keys beneath it are deleted.

member.name: P:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.ISerial.ReceiveTimeout
member.summary: The maximum time that the ASCOM serial port will wait for incoming receive data (seconds, default = 5)
member.value: Integer, serial port timeout in seconds
member.returns: Integer, serial port timeout in seconds.
member.remarks: The minimum delay timout that can be set through this command is 1 seconds. Use ReceiveTimeoutMs to set a timeout less than 1 second.

member.name: P:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.ISerial.ReceiveTimeoutMs
member.summary: The maximum time that the ASCOM serial port will wait for incoming receive data (milliseconds, default = 5000)
member.value: Integer, serial port timeout in milli-seconds
member.returns: Integer, serial port timeout in milli-seconds
member.remarks: If a timeout occurs, an IO timeout error is raised. See ReceiveTimeout for an alternate form using the timeout in seconds.

member.name: P:ASCOM.Utilities.Interfaces.ISerial.PortName
member.summary: Sets the ASCOM serial port name as a string
member.value: Serial port name to be used
member.returns: Current serial port name
member.remarks: This property allows any serial port name to be used, even if it doesn't conform to a format of COMnnn If the required port name is of the form COMnnn then Serial.Port=nnn and Serial.PortName="COMnnn" are equivalent.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Util.WaitForMilliseconds(System.Int32)
member.summary: Pauses for a given interval in milliseconds.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait
member.remarks: Repeatedly puts the calling Win32 process to sleep, totally freezing it, for 10 milliseconds, then pumps events so the script or program calling it will receive its normal flow of events, until the pause interval elapses. If the pause interval is 20 milliseconds or less, the sleep interval is reduced to 0, causing the calling Win32 process to give up control to the kernel scheduler and then immediately become eligible for scheduling.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Util.DMSToDegrees(System.String)
member.summary: Convert sexagesimal degrees to binary double-precision degrees
member.param: The sexagesimal input string (degrees)
member.returns: The double-precision binary value (degrees) represented by the sexagesimal input

remarks.para: The sexagesimal to real conversion methods such as this one are flexible enough to convert just about anything that resembles sexagesimal. Thee way they operate is to first separate the input string into numeric "tokens", strings consisting only of the numerals 0-9, plus and minus, and period. All other characters are considered delimiters. Once the input string is parsed into tokens they are converted to numerics.

If there are more than three numeric tokens, only the first three are considered, the remainder are ignored. Left to right positionally, the tokens are assumed to represent units (degrees or hours), minutes, and seconds. If only two tokens are present, they are assumed to be units and minutes, and if only one token is present, it is assumed to be units. Any token can have a fractionsl part. Of course it would not be normal (for example) for both the minutes and seconds parts to have fractional parts, but it would be legal. So 00:30.5:30 would convert to 1.0 unit.
Note that plain units, for example 23.128734523 are acceptable to the method.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Util.HMSToHours(System.String)
member.summary: Convert sexagesimal hours to binary double-precision hours
member.param: The sexagesimal input string (hours)
member.returns: The double-precision binary value (hours) represented by the sexagesimal input

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Chooser.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Does the work of cleaning up objects used by Chooser
member.param: True if called by the user, false if called by the system
member.remarks: You can't call this directly, use Dispose with no arguments instead.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Chooser.Dispose
member.summary: Cleans up and disposes objects used by Chooser

member.name: P:ASCOM.Utilities.Chooser.DeviceType
member.summary: The type of device for which the Chooser will select a driver. (String, default = "Telescope")
member.value: The type of device for which the Chooser will select a driver. (String, default = "Telescope")
member.returns: The device type that has been set
member.exception: Thrown on setting the device type to empty string
member.remarks:
This property changes the "personality" of the Chooser, allowing it to be used to select a driver for any arbitrary ASCOM device type. The default value for this is "Telescope", but it could be "Focuser", "Camera", etc.
This property is independent of the Profile object's DeviceType property. Setting Chooser's DeviceType property doesn't set the DeviceType property in Profile, you must set that also when needed.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Chooser.Choose
member.summary: Select ASCOM driver to use without pre-selecting in the dropdown list
member.returns: Driver ID of chosen driver
member.remarks:
No driver will be pre-selected in the Chooser's list when the chooser window is first opened. Thrown if the Chooser.DeviceType property has not been set before Choose is called. It must be set in order for Chooser to know which list of devices to display.
This overload is not available through COM, please use "Choose(ByVal DriverProgID As String)" with an empty string parameter to achieve this effect.

member.name: M:ASCOM.Utilities.Chooser.Choose(System.String)
member.summary: Select ASCOM driver to use including pre-selecting one in the dropdown list
member.param: Driver to preselect in the chooser dialogue
member.returns: Driver ID of chosen driver
member.exception: Thrown if the Chooser.DeviceType property has not been set before Choose is called. It must be set in order for Chooser to know which list of devices to display.
member.remarks: The supplied driver will be pre-selected in the Chooser's list when the chooser window is first opened.

member.name: T:ASCOM.Utilities.Chooser
member.summary: The Chooser object provides a way for your application to let your user select the telescope to use.

remarks.para: Calling Chooser.Choose() causes a chooser window to appear, with a drop down selector list containing all of the registered Telescope drivers, listed by the driver's friendly/display name. The user sees a list of telescope types and selects one. Before the OK button will light up, however, the user must click the Setup button, causing the selected driver's setup dialog to appear (it calls the driver's Telescope.SetupDialog() method). When the setup dialog is closed, the OK button will light and allow the user to close the Chooser itself.

The Choose() method returns the DriverID of the selected driver. Choose() allows you to optionally pass the DriverID of a "current" driver (you probably save this in the registry), and the corresponding telescope type is pre-selected in the Chooser's list. In this case, the OK button starts out enabled (lit-up); the assumption is that the pre-selected driver has already been configured.
